hints_html: The acceleration is the rate of change of velocity.
hints_latex: The acceleration is the rate of change of velocity.
hints_raw: The acceleration is the rate of change of velocity.
question: 3 (a)
sols_html:
If s = \(f\)(”t ) is the function describing the position of the particle, then its derivative \(f\)’(t”) is its velocity and its second derivative the acceleration. This means we know that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f''(t) = a(t)\end{aligned}\]

and so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f''(t) = 12t-30\end{aligned}\]

Since this is a polynomial in t of degree one, we know that the velocity must be a polynomial of degree 2:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(t) = at^2+bt+c\end{aligned}\]

whose derivative is 12t-30

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dt}\left( at^2+bt+c \right) = 2at+b\end{aligned}\]

Hence we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 2a = 12 \qquad \text{and} \qquad b=-30\end{aligned}\]

And so the velocity is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(t) = 6t^2-30t+c\end{aligned}\]

for some constant c. Since the velocity after 2 seconds is 0, we actually are being told that \(f\)’(2)=0 and hence

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 6 \cdot 4 - 30 \cdot 2 + c = 0 \qquad \Rightarrow c=36\end{aligned}\]

And so the velocity is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(t) = 6t^2-30t+36\end{aligned}\]

Now, the velocity being the derivative of the position function, we can deduce that it has to be a polynomial of degree 3 and write

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(t) = At^3+Bt^2+Ct+D\end{aligned}\]

and computing its derivative gives us

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(t) = 3At^2+2Bt+C\end{aligned}\]

Hence

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 3A = 6 \qquad \text{and} \qquad 2B=-30 \qquad \text{and} \qquad C=36\end{aligned}\]

So the position function is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(t) = 2t^3-15t^2+36t+D\end{aligned}\]

and we can find out the value of D since we are told that \(f\)(0) = 0 which gives

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle D=0\end{aligned}\]

And so finally, we obtain that the position function is:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(t) = 2t^3-15t^2+36t\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
If \emph{s} = $f$(''t \emph{) is the function describing the position of
the particle, then its derivative $f$'(}t'') is its velocity and its
second derivative the acceleration. This means we know that

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f''(t) = a(t)
\end{align*} and so

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f''(t) = 12t-30
\end{align*} Since this is a polynomial in \emph{t} of degree one,
we know that the velocity must be a polynomial of degree 2:

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f'(t) = at^2+bt+c
\end{align*} whose derivative is 12\emph{t}-30

\begin{align*}
\frac{d}{dt}\left( at^2+bt+c \right) = 2at+b
\end{align*} Hence we have

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
2a = 12 \qquad \text{and} \qquad b=-30
\end{align*} And so the velocity is

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f'(t) = 6t^2-30t+c
\end{align*} for some constant \emph{c}. Since the velocity
after 2 seconds is 0, we actually are being told that $f$'(2)=0 and hence

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
6 \cdot 4 - 30 \cdot 2 + c = 0 \qquad \Rightarrow c=36
\end{align*} And so the
velocity is

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f'(t) = 6t^2-30t+36
\end{align*} Now, the velocity being the derivative of the
position function, we can deduce that it has to be a polynomial of
degree 3 and write

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f(t) = At^3+Bt^2+Ct+D
\end{align*} and computing its derivative gives us

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f'(t) = 3At^2+2Bt+C
\end{align*} Hence

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
3A = 6 \qquad \text{and} \qquad 2B=-30 \qquad \text{and} \qquad C=36
\end{align*}
So the position function is

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f(t) = 2t^3-15t^2+36t+D
\end{align*} and we can find out the value of \emph{D}
since we are told that $f$(0) = 0 which gives

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
D=0
\end{align*} And so finally, we obtain that the position function is:

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f(t) = 2t^3-15t^2+36t
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
If ''s'' = &fnof;(''t '') is the function describing the position of the particle, then its derivative &fnof;'(''t '') is its velocity and its second derivative the acceleration. This means we know that
:<math>\displaystyle
f''(t) = a(t)
</math>
and so
:<math>\displaystyle
f''(t) = 12t-30
</math>
Since this is a polynomial in ''t'' of degree one, we know that the velocity must be a polynomial of degree 2:
:<math>\displaystyle
f'(t) = at^2+bt+c
</math>
whose derivative is 12''t''-30
:<math>
\frac{d}{dt}\left( at^2+bt+c \right) = 2at+b
</math>
Hence we have
:<math>\displaystyle
2a = 12 \qquad \text{and} \qquad b=-30
</math>
And so the velocity is
:<math>\displaystyle
f'(t) = 6t^2-30t+c
</math>
for some constant ''c''. Since the velocity after 2 seconds is 0, we actually are being told that &fnof;'(2)=0 and hence
:<math>\displaystyle
6 \cdot 4 - 30 \cdot 2 + c = 0 \qquad \Rightarrow c=36
</math>
And so the velocity is
:<math>\displaystyle
f'(t) = 6t^2-30t+36
</math>
Now, the velocity being the derivative of the position function, we can deduce that it has to be a polynomial of degree 3 and write
:<math>\displaystyle
f(t) = At^3+Bt^2+Ct+D
</math>
and computing its derivative gives us
:<math>\displaystyle
f'(t) = 3At^2+2Bt+C
</math>
Hence
:<math>\displaystyle
3A = 6 \qquad \text{and} \qquad 2B=-30 \qquad \text{and} \qquad C=36
</math>
So the position function is
:<math>\displaystyle
f(t) = 2t^3-15t^2+36t+D
</math>
and we can find out the value of ''D'' since we are told that &fnof;(0) = 0 which gives
:<math>\displaystyle
D=0
</math>
And so finally, we obtain that the position function is:
:<math>\displaystyle
f(t) = 2t^3-15t^2+36t
</math>
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly stated.
A particle moves in a straight line according to a law of motion s = \(f({t} )\), t \(\geq\) 0, where t is measured in seconds and s in meters. The acceleration function a(t ) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle a(t)=12t-30\end{aligned}\]

The velocity after 2 seconds is 0, and \(f\)(0) = 0.

Find the position function s = \(f({t} )\).

the position function \emph{s} = $f({t} )$.

:<math>\displaystyle
a(t)=12t-30
</math>
The velocity after 2 seconds is 0, and &fnof;(0) = 0.
